Award.AwardTitle: Bijective Combinatorics of Maps: Beyond Boundaries
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project tackles several open problems related to ``maps'', that is, graphs embedded in surfaces. Maps appear naturally in many active areas of research including computer science (for encoding meshes of surfaces), algebraic combinatorics (for studying factorizations in the symmetric group), statistical mechanics (as host of a model), and probability (as a discrete approximation of the random surfaces needed in quantum gravity). In the last decade, building on works by Schaeffer, a bijective approach was developed for several classes of maps. Typically, the bijections obtained give a correspondence between a class of maps, and a class of (decorated) plane trees. Because trees are easier to study than maps, bijections have been key to the solution of several open problems on maps coming from combinatorics, probability theory and theoretical physics. In this project, the P.I. intends to (1) Unify several bijections: this would simplify a review on the bijective approach to maps, and systematize, to some extent, the process of finding bijections. (2) Extend bijections to planar maps with boundaries and to maps of higher genus: this would satisfy some algorithmic needs and might inform recent results from representation theory. (3) Apply a bijective approach to statistical mechanics models on maps: this could provide new models and help understand how metric properties of maps are affected by the Boltzmann probabilities imposed by these models.

The P.I. will actively mentor undergraduate research students and, more generally, foster the mathematical curiosity of young students. The combinatorics of maps is an ideal subject for initiating undergraduate students to research as it requires only a limited mathematical background but can lead to very rich problems. Moreover, the visual nature of maps gives many opportunities to convey mathematical ideas to a young audience during talks. The P.I. also plans to write a review article which would serve has an entry point for non-specialists willing to learn the bijective approach to maps. Such a survey is particularly needed because maps appear at the frontier of several research communities. The bijective approach to maps has practical applications in computer science. Indeed, maps are the combinatorial structures underlying the meshes of surfaces, and this creates a need for efficient coding algorithms. Bijections between maps and trees are the basis of the most efficient coding algorithms to date. Thus, extending bijections to new classes of maps is likely to improve the coding methods for the corresponding meshes. Other possible byproducts of bijections are random sampling and drawing algorithms for meshes.

This project aimed at studying maps, that is, surfaces decomposed into polygons. The motivations for studying maps are manifolds, because maps are  fundamental combinatorial structures appearing in many areas of mathematics. The most immediate application of maps is for computer science: maps are the standard way surfaces are handled in computer graphics applications. Less obvious motivations come from  algebraic combinatorics (for studying factorizations in the symmetric group), statistical mechanics (where maps play the role of a random environment hosting of a physics model), and probability (as mas are discrete approximations of the random surfaces needed in quantum gravity). 

In this project, the P.I. has solved several open questions about maps using bijections between maps and simpler combinatorial objects such as trees.  Such bijections are desirable because they allow one to translate questions about maps into (simpler) questions about trees. This bijective approach to maps was pioneered by Gilles Schaeffer is the late 1990s (and further developed by many other researchers, including the P.I.) and has already led to impressive breakthroughs for many problems on maps coming from combinatorics, probability theory and theoretical physics. 

 

One of the main contributions of this project was to make the  bijective approach to maps much more systematic. Indeed, in a collaboration with Eric Fusy, the P.I. has developed and applied a general method for finding bijections between maps and trees:

- In a joint work with Eric Fusy, the P.I. has developed a ``master bijection'' which establishes a universal correspondence between maps and trees.

- The P.I. subsequently applied the ``master bijection'' approach to recover, unify, and extend the many known bijections for maps. In this approach, a key role is played by certain canonical orientations characterizing classes of the maps (this is the most technical part of the applications mentioned below).

- The master bijection was generalized to hypermaps, and used to handle additional structure on maps, such as statistical mechanics models.  

- The master bijection approach was also generalized to maps with boundaries.

- Lastly, the master bijection was used to design a random generation algorithm for planar maps, and obtain results about the distribution of distances in random maps.

 


Aside from this ``master bijection'' approach to maps, the author has solved several problems related to maps. Most importantly,

- In a collaboration with Mireille Bousquet-Melou, the P.I. has solved the Potts models on maps. More precisely, the partition function of this statistical mechanics model was characterized by a system of differential equations. This type of characterization is simpler and different in nature from what has been described in the Mathematics Physics for any similar model. This open new questions for these other models.  

- In a collaboration with Nicolas Curien and Gregory Miermont, the P.I. has studied the percolation model on maps. We proved that there is a phase transition for this model and that the percolation cluster at criticality converges toward a model of random surfaces with holes defined in a previous paper of Le Gall and Miermont.

- The P.I has shown that the eigenvalues of GOE random matrices satisfy an analogue of the Harer-Zagier formula.

-In a collaborations with Alejandro Morales and Richard Stanley a formula was established for certain connection coefficients of the symmetric group and for the  separation probabilities of products of permutations.
